title: Lamppost light sensor holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I needed to install a new light sensor on my front lawn lamppost, but the one I bought didn't fit in the old one's mount. Hence this thing. I used some J-B Weld to make a watertight seal between the sensor and the holder after installing it.

Measure your lamppost's diameter, the size of the screws you'll use, the separation of the screw holes, and the diameter of the new sensor. Update the relevant values in the SCAD file. You'll probably have to play around with the height, depth, and angle values to get something that both looks good and is sturdy enough. The part is rotated so that no support material should be needed.

print_settings.Notes:: after the print, remove the supports with a razor knife and needle nose pliers. Then go fix your truck.

description.text:
I have a 2011 F350 Super Duty with bucket seats and a big center console. When I bought the Truck one of the bumpers for the console lid was gone. Ford does not sell just the bumpers, and I'm not going to shell out $580 for a new console lid with the bumpers. So i made this, and put it in and everything is good, no more lid rattle.
I printed this in TPU with 3 walls and 3 top and bottom layers. with 30% infill. layer height was .15mm and cooling fan set to on. I used Simplify3D and printed it ball side down, with supports. If it fails and I have to print another i'd do it with about 5% infill and 2 layers top and bottom and sides. It's not as squishy as I'd have liked,
it's also about .7mm thicker then the OE one, so if your replacing one of the back bumpers you should trim about .5-.75mm off the ball end with a razor knife.
Being thicker it closes a bit harder then without the bumper, but again, as long as it stops the rattle, it's OK in my book.
Please comment if you make it and it works for you, or if you have any way to make it better. As always i uploaded the original Sketchup file if you want to modify it.

You will need 4 of 10mm x 3mm spacer for cam mount and 8 screws for spacer.

Just a simple clip on Spool holder.

The Clip is rather strong, but has an extra bolt to be fastened to the Frame. Rather safe than sorry! :)

This is a simple enclosure to attach a RasPi on the official 7" touchscreen to a 2020 cross-member. I set this up to work on my Kossel Plus with Peaberry's Kossel Base Stands and my Parametric Kossel Base Panels.

This is my most complex design so far, but it's still fairly simple in the great scheme of things. The faceplate mounting measurements are from the official data-sheet:

https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/hardware/display/7InchDisplayDrawing-14092015.pdf

The main shell is basically an extruded projection of the angled faceplate. The mounting tabs are all just rectangles with cylinders removed.

If folks are interested (let me know in the comments), I may be able to put together a parametric version for different mounting heights / case depths.

title: 70mm EDF thrust tube (Dr. Mad Thrust Alloy EDF)

description.text:
This is a thrust tube for a Dr. Mad Thrust 70mm EDF and designed for high speeds

(I'm not an aerospace engineer, but i tried to design it as good as possible, and after schübeler's description on their website: http://www.schuebeler-jets.de/en/edf-know-how-en/configuration-of-the-channels)

I'm positive that it will fit on other brand EDF housings, but in case it doesn't I included the 123Design files for you to change the design for your needs
(and please upload it so others can use it, mention my name and include a link to my design :D).

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm - (propably as rough as you would like)

Infill:

100

Notes:

Print the tube and the wire-fairing upright, gives you the best result.

I printed the thrust tube with Hobbyking PLA at 0.2mm layer resolution and with 100% infill
(weight: ~70g).
You should be fine with approx. 15% infill and 0.4 mm walls (looks like it should print just fine with triangular infill) and you should end up with a weight of approx. 40g.

Mounting of the wire-fairing

Mount the thrust tube to your EDF and put the wires through the hole.
Then slip the fairing over the motor wires and glue it into place with a few drops of CA.

trimming of mounting tabs

You might have to trim down the mounting tabs on the sides, so they don't interere with your EDF one's.

Smoothing of the inner surface (not necessary)

You could try to sand down the inner part of the tube to get a bit higher efficiency out of it as the print isn't 100% smooth (I use my thrust tubes straight from the printer and didn't notice any loss of power on my models).

author: MathewFPV

description.text: A drill bit holder for bits with a 1/4" shank, presented in a decorative drill-shaped holder! With room in the middle for a pencil or spare bits.

I bought some drill bits at Harbor Freight that all had the same 1/4" shank on them. They came in a blister pack (obviously, see above re: Harbor Freight) and I realized as I walked past the tool boxes that I had no place to keep them sorted. They won't fit in any of my existing bit holders because of the 1/4" shank, which means that they will either stay awkwardly in their blister pack or kick around loose at the bottom of a drawer.
But then I remembered I can make my own organizer on my 3D printer!
Using Adobe Illustrator, I placed 13 1/4" hexagons in a circle, each 27.7 degrees apart. Then I cut the hexagons out of a ring and then saved the file as a SVG.
The SVG was imported into a new build on Tinkercad, and extruded into a cylinder. I wanted to either make the cylinder a little more decorative and/or find a way to keep the bits secure but easy to pull out. I decided security was going to be a 2.0 fix, and went instead for pretty. I replaced the cylinder with a shape from the library called "twisted polygon" that resembled a drill bit. Perfect! Then I chopped off the top of the build at an angle so that each bit would be accessible.
After printing, I find that the holes mostly grip the bits just tight enough but a few were too tight and needed some sanding/reaming (your mileage may vary). If I print it again, I'll scale up the whole object by about 3% to give ample space in each hole, or maybe just go with round holes instead. I think that some of the bits get stuck because of irregularities in how the shank is crimped to the drill bit.
Possible ways to Improve:

  1. Add magnets, tension springs, a rubber band, or some other way to keep the bits safely in the organizer while still easy to access
    1. Can this be done in a way that saves plastic? Add some voids, or make it smaller?
    2. Maybe a spiral shape to start with instead of a ring, so that the height of the holes goes up as it swirls up the mountain?
this is a work in progress

This is a basic design for a 3D Printed Pine Wood Derby Racer. The basic design as based off of my own Pine Wood Derby car I carved out of a block of wood when I was in the cub scouts.

At the upcoming East Coast RepRap Festival, we will be holding a 3D Printed Pine Wood Derby race! We will follow all of the Boy Scouts of America Rules, except we will 3D print the bodies of the cars!

More details to come on the when and where of the race and #ERRF2018, but for now, I wanted to share the example of a 3D Printed Pine Wood Derby car to get your creative and competitive juices flowing!

As far as getting your completed car as close to but not exceeding the 5 ounce limit, you will have to play with perimeters and infill percentages to get you the right mix for the ideal weight. Good luck!

ERRF2018 3DPWD Car Rules

All parts must be 3DPrinted except the car axles and wheels.
Wheels & axles will be official BSA standard issue from Revell.
No polished, enhanced or coated wheels or axels are allowed.
Chassis weights are allowed.
Car width may not exceed 2 1/4 inches
Car length may not exceed 7 inches
Car may not exceed 5 ounces
Any details must fit between length, width and weight requirements.
Car must be free wheeling, starting and propulsion or other mechanical devices are not allowed.
Only dry lubricants are allowed.
3DPWD entrant cars must be built in the current year.

www.eastcoastreprapfest.com
@ERRF2018

This is my take on a great gadget. The basic device is great all I have done is add a couple of bearings to each end to reduce friction on the belt the idea being to make the gauge more sensitive and better repeatable readings.
Note: You will need a few more things in addition to the spring (have a look at calviniba's original post) I used these small flanged bearings 3mm inner 10mm outer, I used M3 x 20mm bolts and I used M3 washers between everything (top, in between the bearings and the base) the idea is to make sure the bearings are free.
The base and indicator I have modified the stick part is un touched.

description.text: A quick remix to change the eyes a bit and smooth out the surface. I also plane-cut the bottom to give all of the draping equal(ish) footing.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

Notes:

Print in 3 perimeters and it's a pretty sturdy model. No infill. No supports. Use either a raft or a brim of about 5mm. The hardest part is the bottom, you will need a cooling fan to keep the overhangs from curling, otherwise the bottom parts can get knocked off before they fuse to each other. Once past the draping apex, it is an easy print.

Post Processing

You can use an Xacto knife or clippers to trim excess from the draping or reshape curves. A heat gun or torch can be used to clean up "shave" marks or strings.

Design

I used Meshmixer to resculpt the eyes, smooth the surface, and plane-cut the bottom.

comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text: This is "LD" branded, glow in the dark ABS. Fairly generic stuff, actually. I have used Hatchbox GITD PLA in the past and it was fine as well, but slightly more glossy.
comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text: Thanks, I tried the hatchbox but it prints as a kind of translucent green colour rather than white
comments.author: robbynowell

comments.text: Ah, I understand what you mean. I've only printed with 3 GITD filaments. Makerbot, Hatchbox, and LD. It's been a while since I printed with the Makerbot filament, but it was similar to the LD in opacity, but ever so slightly more green tint. LD is a little bit off white in the green spectrum. I would rank them Hatchbox<Makerbot<LD<white. They are all translucent, but Hatchbox is the most translucent I think. The only thing about the LD filament is that it has a very palpable texture to it, which some people may not like. It kind of feels like fine sandpaper. Makerbot filament was more smooth. Hatchbox was in between. Of course this is all subject to the person mixing the pellets and pigments at the factory on a particular day and who is supplying the bulk material stock.
comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text: Thanks. I have some esun glow in the dark which I think is the same as Inland. It glows nice but boy is it brittle.
comments.author: robbynowell

comments.text: FWIW - Inland GITD glows brightly and has a mostly white, kinda off white print color. I've used it and Hatchbox GITD and prefer the Inland stuff. Not sure who makes it for them, but it glows much brighter that Hatchbox's does.

One of the things I liked about some brands of earbuds is the sliding clip to keep the earphones from tangling up. I break and have to purchase new earbuds every six to eight months (I'm rough on them - go figure). In any case I iterated a new design for an Earphone/Earbud anti tangle slide clip that can be 3d printed.  It's designed for earphone wires that are about 1.5 mm thick.  This design seems to work well and has become quite popular among my associates. Review the build details then have a go and print out your own.

Printed in ABS on a monocote over glass surface with aquanet spray - no stick down issues. Print temp 230C, Bed temp 110C first layer 100C hereafter.   
CAUTION: Because these are very small they print very quickly and will remain easily deformable until cool.  You need to allow the bed and parts to cool to about room temp after printing - this will usually take 2-5 miutes.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: bed level helper for wanhao duplicator i3 (and plus)

description.text:
Two versions of a very basic bed leveler I designed to help with my own printer (an i3 plus)... one with text and the other plain.

Hang both of these at opposite ends of the top x axis rod, and slowly bring Z down until one or both of the levelers almost touch the bed.

Adjust your bed to make sure it's level (essentially, the same vertical distance from the bottom of both levelers). Eyeballing the distance between bed and leveler should be good, in most cases. OR, if there's just not much available range to the screws, adjust your Z axis couplers and then adjust the bed leveling screws.

Bed level should be checked at the minimum, at each of the Y ends of the bed, and optimally, even at the middle. Check both Y extents first, and then the middle. Adjust leveling screws as necessary.

Yet another Companion Cube.

I created this in Autodesk Inventor, really just to learn how to use that program. I primarily use Slic3r. I primarily use this just for decoration.

YOU NEED TO SCALE UP BY 2540% to get it to be the size intended (58 x 58 x 58) mm.
The bottom part doesn't look very good because of the supports, but I don't really care. I would recommend supporting bridges for the bottom, but I have not personally tried that.

I made this as one big print so I wouldn't have to mess with glue or anything like that. The sides look very good at 175 micron resolution. I am planning on getting my gf to paint the companion cube, and I will upload more pictures then.

Also, I printed with grey Hatchbox PLA.

description.text:
This is one of the characters for my 3D printed tabletop game. Please check out the websites and my social pages for more information.

As you can see the version 1 models are okay, I tried to keep the face pretty symmetrical I wanted to keep them with a more dwarf tank type character. The dwarf may not be as short as I had initially hoped, and this may be something that will need to be changed in a further revision. Other than that I’m fairly happy with the character. I wanted to give it the “Viking hat” since I do sometimes see this with the Dwarfs, a massive hammer which was hard to move to the correct place, and also a big beard. In the end, I’m fairly happy with how this model turned out. I’d love to hear your thoughts regarding it!

Esta es una implementacion de https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2017486, a la cual le adicione algunas partes para adaptarlo al extrusor L3k.
Esta sonda mide alturas no es afectada por la temperatura de la cama y mide sobre la misma por lo que se puede cambiar el cristal por otro sin tener que realizar ningun ajuste.

Para la calibracion si utiliza Repetier or Simplify3d programa esta 3 macros para ayudarle a determinar la altura de la sonda una vez obtenido este parametro no debera ajustar nunca mas.
1-Inicialization.
M80;
M280 P0 S0;
G28;
G90;
G1 Z10.00;
G1 X70.00 Y80.00;
M400;
M280 P0 S90;
G91;

2-Down
G1 Z-0.1
M119;
3-Slow down.
G1 Z-0.01
M119;

Para la calibracion ejecute este Gcode una sola vez:

M280 P0 S0; probe up
G28; home
G90; absolute coord
G1 Z10.00; Z=10
G1 X70.00 Y80.00; one point in the center of the bed
G1 Z0; Z=0
M400; wait for finnish

El nozzle se habra parado en el centro de la cama , calibrelo a la altura correcta puede utilizar una hoja de papel para eso. En este punto el nozle se encuentra a 0.1 de altura.
Ejecute la macro 1.
descienda el nozzle utilizando la macro 2/3, puede repetir varias veces hasta detecter el numero exacto en que se enciende la sonda.
Al numero obtenido por ejemplo 9.31 sume 0.1 , sera 9.4 en el ejemplo nuestra altura de sonda y programela en el Marlin o por medio del gcode M851 S-9.4 en nuestro ejemplo.

Numeros mas negativos el nozzle estara mas cerca de la cama, Determine el correcto porbando y este de mantendra invariable.

This Probe is an implementation of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2017486,I added some part to use it with L3K You can adapt it to every extruder..

The most important part is to know the distance between noozle and the activation of the calibration probe, When you get this distance it is for ever the same,so you never need to calibrate de bed again.

Calibration tips, using Repetier or Simplify3d program these 3 gcodes on 3 diferent macros.

1-Inicialization.
M80;
M280 P0 S0;
G28;
G90;
G1 Z10.00;
G1 X70.00 Y80.00;
M400;
M280 P0 S90;
G91;

2-Down
G1 Z-0.1
M119;
3-Slow down.
G1 Z-0.01
M119;

The procedure is prety simple,
1.Run thi gcode one time to adjust 1 point in your bed:

M280 P0 S0; probe up
G28; home
G90; absolute coord
G1 Z10.00; Z=10
G1 X70.00 Y80.00; one point in the center of the bed
G1 Z0; Z=0
M400; wait for finnish

After run your nozzle will be positioned in some place (adjust the gcode to place it in the center of the bed). Adjust the bed to the right distance, placing a sheet of paper under the nozzle ) at this point yout nozzle is near 0.1 mm from the bed.(Preheat the noozle and the bed for better results).

Calibracion
Run macro 1.
Run Macro 2 and 3 until the probe is on. Take Z heigth. It will be something between 9 and 10.
When you get the munver add 0.1 to this and program it to the controles using this Gcode or placing the value in Marlin.
Place it in the programming M851 S-9.31 ( graget negatives numer are closer )

Here is the prototype of the multi-axis robot we are working on. More info at www.botomaton.com
Videos at Botomaton Labs (YouTube) http://www.youtube.com/user/botomatonlabs?feature=results_main This Video shows the bot during initial motor tuning. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EIl15-zMA8k&feature=plcp NEW July 29, 2012, Watch the prototype botomaton get assembled: video here: http://botomaton.com/videoStreamPrototype.html Revised .ai files have been uploaded on 7/25/12, due to some changes. Download the BotoP2.zip instead of BotoP1. Just uploaded on 7/24/12 a revised BOM parts list. Download and use Parts List-RVSN.pdf. An electrical wiring diagram is forthcoming.

There are 2 types of material 3mm MDF and 58mil (.058 inch) art-board We got the MDF from Lowes and the art-board from Michaels When cutting the material from BotoP2.zip ai files, files names ending in thin are cut on the 58 mil art board (two files). Files ending in 2x are to be cut twice. We used a Full Spectrum MLE-40 laser cutter. For the cuts on the MDF we used: Red 30% speed 100% power (15ma).
Blue or Purple 30% speed 100% power.
Black (lettering) 100% speed 5% power. It takes about 2.5 hours to cut everything. The gripper is not part of the BOM it is from RobotShop. It mounts to the toolmount2.ai assembly. The software to operate the bot is in the file "BotomatonProtoRel.idl". You will need to download the graphical language called Azido from www.Azido.net in order to compile and run. Also, you will need to download the Nexys3 system description (device driver) from the same site.

I've included the FreeCAD source so you can modify it for any nut size you want.
WARNING: STL is exported in mm. You'll have to scale down 25.4 times (0.03937 or 3.937%) if you want to print it in inches.

description.text:
I used KatTrue's parametric center finder to create a 50 mm long version with a 3 mm hole in the center. It is handy for when you need to find the center of an object.

An example would be if you had a board and you needed to cut it in half lengthwise. You hold it so each little round cylinder is next to the edge of the board. You then put your pencil / pen in the hole and slide it down a board.

Filament is Makergeeks sun punch yellow:
https://www.makergeeks.com/products/maker-series-pla-3d-filament-175mm-sun-punch-yellow-1kg

title: Simple Optical Breadboard Webcam Target Mount

description.text:
The webcam mount used in my interference experiment: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZH40mvSFI-g

I modified the original #8 screw mount design so it could additionally be 1" center breadboard mounted or breadboard mounted with 3 steel bearing balls to keep it from rocking.

I printed mine in PLA--except for the adjusters, which I did in ABS.

After printing, I tapped the holes with a 3mm tap on both the tilt and adjuster parts.
For my project, I just glue-gun glued the camera directly to the mount.

For those who would like to help me continue making things, here is my Patreon Page: https://www.patreon.com/brendaem

title: Razor RipStik Casterboard Wall Mount Rack

description.text:
This rack is designed to hold the Razor RipStik Casterboard horizontally against a wall. The RipStik (Rip Stick, if you misspell it) is a fun scooter for my kids, but I was tired of them lying on the floor in the garage, so I designed this rack so that they could be hung up on the wall. There is a rib in the middle of the holder that fits into the groove in the RipStik, centering it on the rack. The RipStik can point either way. I did find that the center of gravity is slightly off from the groove, but the holder is wide enough it stays balanced on the rack.

Once printed, simply screw into the wall using two screws. The RipStick is heavy enough that you'll need to either screw into studs or use anchors appropriate for your wall type. I printed three copies at 35% infill just to be safe and they hold quite well. If you print at 20% and it works for you, please leave a comment and I'll update the print specs.

This is my first model posted to Thingiverse, so constructive feedback is welcome!

description.text: Removed 1 mount on the back and added on the pelvis, reducing spinal and head fins and broke the Trident into 2 parts (for small printer).
A wall mount for the Oculus Rift sensor.

Here's a board I designed back in 2006.  At the time, I was obsessed with making easy to use controller modules in the smallest packages possible.  This control board should fit into a DIP44 socket.
Includes a nice LDO 5V regulator I found, and an onboard RS232 line converter.  The line voltage RS232 pins and the power and ground pins are on a screw terminal header, and just about everything is brought out to the pins on the bottom.  I tried to get as much IO as possible, but obviously there are some pins that didn't make it.  Includes ISP header, and also has the watch crystal for RTC.
It's a pretty neat board, and it can be assembled by hand for about $20.

Here's the parts list, with Digikey part numbers:
  • 296-9593-1-ND - IC DRVR/RCVR RS-232 1-CH 16-SSOP
  • 576-1276 - IC REG LDO 500MA 5.0V LN SOT223
  • ATMEGA644-20AU-ND - IC AVR MCU FLASH 64K 44TQFP
  • PX200BCT-ND - RESONATR CERM W/CAP 20.00MHZ SMD
  • 300-8341-1-ND - CRYSTAL 32.768 KHZ 6PF SMD
  • 516-1436-1 - LED 469NM BLUE DIFF 1206
  • 516-1444-1 - LED 520NM GREEN DIFF 1206
  • 277-1275 - CONN TERM BLOCK 2.54MM 4POS
  • 311-10.0KFCT-ND - RES 10.0K OHM 1/4W 1% 1206 SMD
  • 311-470ECT-ND - RES 470 OHM 1/4W 5% 1206 SMD
  • PCC1901CT-ND - CAP .47UF 25V CERAMIC Y5V 1206
  • 490-1775-1-ND - CAP CER .1UF 50V 10% X7R 1206

Basic Prop Guard for 5 inch Propellers on motors with mounting screws between 16 and 19 millimeters on center. So far, the top is intended to be held on with Zip Ties. General purpose is to make my propellers "Finger-Safe" so I can fly my 210 indoors without it trying to eat my children.

I will post flight my findings regarding the added Drag, and 200g weight, after I've been able to test.

UPDATE: The two "Crosshatch" files are an upgraded version that make it easier to install on an existing build by just un-screwing the motors and sliding cage on. New design should add or maintain top and bottom structural integrity, while increasing airflow and the sides reduce overall weight. All of the Overhangs are less than 45 degrees and should be printable without supports. My Kid's fingers still fit in through the bottom, but they kinda have to Work for it.

title: LED strip mount for Prusa I3 MK2S

description.text:
Unfortunately, the Prusa still doesn't come with LEDs, which is a shame because we need to see the prints and we want our printers inside some cabinet so they don't bother us so much with the noise. This is another attempt at having the LEDs installed without compromising the build volume much.

Pic of the table is with only LED lights.

In this case, I compromised 10mm in the height (now max height is 190mm). And that's because I overlooked that the filament needs clearance over it so the extruder assembly doesn't shear it. Somebody more clever could make a curved support to overcome that. As always, the ipts are available for you to change them.

I'm just too lazy, and since the problem only happens in the last 20mm each side, I still have full build height for 200mm of the X axis. Which I never really needed to use!

Have a great day!

description.text:
I needed a rack to keep all of my 3D printer tools/accessories neatly organized. Since my printer is housed in an unfinished portion of my basement, I designed a rack that fits between two exposed wood studs so I could screw it between them. Thus, I designed this rack to be 264mm in width. If your studs are not that spacing, you may need to adjust the model. Sorry, I had not yet learned parametric modeling when I built this model, so you'll have to adjust it by hand. Or add wood shims. ;-)

This rack organizes the following:

  • A multitool (e.g. Leatherman), needle-nose pliers, and the flush snippers (or any three similar two-handled tools)
  • A power plug (I haven't installed a switch for my PSU, so when I'm not using it, I unplug my 3D printer and hang the plug from this rack, keeping it off my workbench)
  • 9 slots for tweezers or binder clips
  • 3 sizes of screw drivers
  • An X-acto knife (blade down into a slot for safety)
  • A 3D print removal tool (long spatula)
  • 5 box cutter blades
  • 3 microSD cards
  • A USB stick
  • A glue stick
  • A digital caliper
  • 4 Allen wrenches (sized to the 4 that came with my Anet A8)
  • 4 pens of various sizes
  • A rotary tool (e.g. Dremmel) head (I have my rotary tool mounted to the wall and use an extension that's much easier for fine handiwork)
  • 6 rotary tool bit

This rack is wider than my print bed, so I split it into two parts with a tongue-and-groove joint. They friction-fit together just fine, but you could glue it if you felt the need.

title: Extruded Aluminum Kossel Filament Spool Holder Free Standing

description.text:
I wanted a nice looking filament spool holder to go with my Kossel Mini. I used the same 15x15mm OpenBeam or Misumi HFS3-1515 that is used in the Kossel Mini frame.
The lengths of extruded aluminum used was 3 x 15cm and 2 x 20cm so about 85cm of extruded aluminum was used. This should accommodate just about any size of spool. You can of course make it whatever size you want. The rod spacer doubles as a means to prevent the rod from accidently slipping from side to side. It is made for something like 8mm or 5/16' smooth rod. I made it to size but after slicing my printer made it a tad loose so I scaled it at 0.93% to be perfectly snug on an 8mm rod. You can scale the spacer to be snug on whatever size rod you want.
Some filing and heat may be needed to get all the pieces to fit together depending on how your printer prints the parts.

title: Jack O'Lantern with Snap On Faces

description.text:
Why have one face for your Jack O'Lantern when you could swap them out?

This Jack O'Lantern has interchangeable front and back faces so you can change what you want it to look like without printing a whole new thing! If you have a good light inside you should be able to have one side facing forward while the other projects out the back. Finally, the faces are printed flat so the designs are less limited by gravity.

I will continue to model and post new faces as I have time.

So far there's:

  • Jack Skellington from Disney's A Nightmare Before Christmas (by Tim Burton) [updated for ease of clip insertion]
  • Oogie Boogie from Disney's A Nightmare Before Christmas (by Tim Burton)
  • Galactic Empire Logo from Star wars
  • A traditional Jack o'Lantern Face
  • A Dia Del Los Muertos Skull
  • A silly face with a tongue sticking out
  • A homage to the Simpson's cyclops alien, Kang
  • The bio-hazard symbol
  • The Dark Knight logo
  • Colorado State University logo
  • Chestburster from Alien remixed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:500093
  • 3 Eyed face inspired by the Toy Story Aliens

NOTE: The Chestburster remix hasn't been tested yet so I don't know how it will print, if the clips can hold it or if will throw off the balance of the jack o'lantern. Looks cool tho (thanks to #Geoffro 's awesome model) and the mouth should glow since I added a tube there.

If you don't see what you want check out the Remixes.
Dingoboy71 made some cool ones:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2598803

I noticed that the projections weren't... awesome. This was partially due to the pumpkin walls being so thick and the edges weren't all angled towards a central point. To work around this, I added a "slide" concept, flat cut out that would attach like a Jack o'Lantern face. This gives a much better projection result and is faster to print.

I'm also posting a blank/solid face and slide so that you can either have a closed side or you can use it as your own template for creating a new face. It has an arrow to indicate which end is up and a groove to denote the usable space. I'm looking forward to see what you creative re-mixers come up with. To make make it easier, I exported the template as a DXF, SKP, and OBJ as well as an STL.

You need:

  • 1 Mid Pumpkin
  • 2 Faces (or 1 Face and 1 slide)
  • 8 Clips (select the tighter margin clips if you have an accurate filament/printer or are enlarging the print)
  • 1 Stem

NOTE: I posted a high rez no clips mid in case someone wants to do something crazy like print it at 300% with no infill and rig some magnets to hold the faces on. DO NOT use this STL if you are going to use the clips.

Finally, an LED tea light to light it up at night. I have a large (2 inch diameter) tea light and there's lots of room for it.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.27mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used 3 shells for the first one, but for the 2nd one I only used two and the light comes through more and makes the whole thing glow when using a super bright LED.

After printing, insert the 8 clips in the slots on the Mid Pumpkin piece. I recommend putting the stiffer end of the clip into the mid pumpkin so the clips don't pull out when you remove a face. Then line up the face with the clips and snap it on. Finally, screw on the stem.

This is a HUGE model of the 4-8-8-4 Big Boy, an American steam locomotive used by Union Pacific Railroad from 1941 into the 1960s. A special project commissioned by MakerBot to test limits of 3D printing, it was created and assembled by Paul Fischer.
Fischer spent between 700 and 800 hours drafting and another 1,000 hours 3D printing the locomotive on a MakerBot Replicator 2 Desktop 3D Printer. The finished engine is six feet long.
Not a project for the faint of heart or short of time!

Follow the "'Big Boy' Assembly' instructions in the PDF under the Files section.
Sanding to fit pieces together will be required. The amount of sanding will depend on how many shells you use in MakerWare. Parts were designed without tolerances. Sanding to fit will be required.
Pieces will likely need to be replated in MakerWare before printing.

comments.text:
The wheels on opposite ends of axles should be quartered, 90 degrees apart. This is so the loco can start no matter where it stopped, even with a piston fully extended.
Union Pacific had right hand lead. The right hand wheels are 90 degrees ahead of the left.

I am totally dumbstruck. This is awesome. I am printing this at 95% on a UP! desk printer and so far all is well. The front engine truck is almost finished.
Reading about curling problems, I solved it by making an enclosure around the printer from perspex so no draft can upset the printing. Since I have done that my warping problems have disappeared. It is important to wait till all is at temperature of about 100 C if you use ABS. For PLA it is about 60 C. I have painted the printer plate with green heat sensitive paint and that works really good.

comments.author: TobyGadd

comments.text:
Thanks!
When I started this project....I was a newbie too!!! LOL. The blue painters tape works.....3M double-sided tape really works...but takes time to set up the next build.
The one thing I did find is...keep the printer in a fairly warm area when printing. Curling will happen more often when the room temp is low. I was printing in my basement...during the warmer months I didn't have much curling ( Room temp about 70 degrees). When it's got colder in the fall/ winter ( room temp at or below 60) I had a lot of curling even with the double sided tape.
As for customizing...I didn't need to. There are some items on Thingiverse that could be used to help printing...but I never tried them.
comments.author: TobyGadd

title: Couch Sofa Release Lever Slip-on Replacement Fix

description.text:
The release lever for my couch snapped-off, so I designed this fix for it. Since a "stub" of the original lever still remained, I designed this thing to slip on over the remaining stub. Printed in black PLA to match the couch, though I realize this makes it a bit hard to see in the photos.

The first photo shows the printed part attached to the couch. The second shows the "stub" that the printed part fits over. The third is a reference photo of a still-intact release lever. The fourth is just the part by itself.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20
Fusion360. The .f3d file is included if you wish to tweak it based on the specifics of how your handle broke.

author: jasonemock

description.text:
I buy lots of these sterilite containers. I imagine a lot of 3D printing hobbyists do. Frequent usage means the clips eventually break. Instead of having to spend another $5 - $12 dollars and throw away a perfectly good container, I drafted a replacement clip.

I know it's lame, but I use a lot of them and it is wasteful to have to purchase again. The attached image is the container where I keep my coffee. Of course that's going to break first, using it everyday for over 2 years.

PLA
.3mm Draft
No Support
Hollow / Shell, No Infill

With these basic settings the printed design is stronger than the factory clip.

I've always wanted a cool looking Nerf shotgun so I took matters into my own hands. I've designed a number of parts to convert a Nerf Mega Magnus into a really sweet looking shotgun!

Please note: The installation of these parts requires the disassembly of your blaster. A hand saw and drill are required for the modification of the blaster and installation of the parts. Additional materials, such as screws/bolts and various diameters of PVC, are required. This is not a "bolt on" or "print and play" kit.

The installation of these parts requires the disassembly of your blaster. A hand saw and drill are required for the modification of the blaster and installation of the parts. Additional materials are required as follows:

Barrel and pump grip
additional materials required:
-1 inch PVC pipe (outside diameter approximately 33.5mm)
-Priming bars on both sides of the blaster to connect the pump grip to the Magnus' top slide
-Screws for securing the priming bars to the pump grip and Magnus' top slide
-A few scraps of fabric to pad the inside of the pump grip
Cuts required:
-The front muzzle of the blaster needs to be cut in order to fit into the 3D printed muzzle

shoulder stock
additional materials required:
-1 inch CPVC pipe (outside diameter approximately 29mm)
-3/4 inch CPVC pipe (outside diameter approximately 22.5mm) needs to fit inside 29mm pipe listed above
-1/2 inch CPVC pipe (outside diameter approximately 16mm)
-A metal pin (a thick nail works just fine for this)
-(optional) A spring to make the adjustable stock control spring loaded
Cuts required:
-The top slide of the blaster needs to be shortened at an angle.
-A lock in the blaster controlling whether or not the blaster can fire while the breech is open needs to be disabled for the blaster to function.

Side mounted dart holder
additional materials required:
-Two screws

top mounted rail
additional materials required:
-Two screws

For assembly instructions please refer to this album:
https://imgur.com/a/lGhdk

description.text:
Tightening and pre-screwing tool made on the basis of "Turbine Rotary Tool 60,000 rpm
By RichMac »
This embodiment is integrated into an industrial tool for transferring a plug onto a container. The component is taken up by the vacuum, the rotational drive by an air flow

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Resolution:

0.1

comments.text: Well done, a useful adaptation of the the turbine.
comments.author: RichMac

comments.text:
Hello Richard,
First, it does not rotate at 60,000 rpm. I use the pressure drop of my pneumatic network to limit the flow and the speed of the air. The connection is a 4x2mm pipe. The air is then distributed in the turbine through 4 orifices. There are therefore four helical flows which circulate in operation. This is the best compromise I have found in order to get a speed adapted to my need (the noise of the 747 is not there ...). I did not measure the speed, but I estimate it between 500 and 800 rpm
In order to gain in torque and not to "stall" too early, I work on the weight of the shaft (in stainless steel) and the tooling in the lower part. The aim is to have sufficient kinetic energy to carry out the pre-screwing.
The final screwing is carried out by another equipment using a brushless motor. This creation is used to allow transport, without the hood falling, to the final equipment.
My post is not complete yet. It lacks a video and details on how it works. I must also share the nomenclature of the necessary equipment. My first goal is to see the potential for interest in this creation.
I hope I have answered your questions
comments.author: RichMac

description.text:
Add some a couple of lenses to your Kinect to vary the focal length, and increase the resolution. The lens holder slides in and out so you can set your degree of magnification. I use it in combination with reconstructMe for obtaining 3D models of objects.
My design path:  ooml -> openscad -> stl -> printrBot

• Print out holderFlat.stl (3 parts to be put together).
  • Screw the horizontal bar to the main body (use nut).
  • Slide in the lens holder and maybe a set screw (should look like holderPutTogether.stl).
  • Put some el cheapo lenses from some reading glasses.
  • Clip onto your Kinect, and start using.

description.text:
UPDATE: The templates work INCREDIBLY well. Photos have been uploaded.

We were able to adjust the temps on the hot wire and cut through foam great, and the template at 3mm thick printed from eSUN PETG held up very well. You have to keep moving, or the wire will start to sink in to the plastic, but we started to get the hang of it.

I will be writing up a more thorough set of instructions with measurements as we near completion. We're still figuring it out as we go. I have an additional 3 templates that I had to design to make this work, and I will be uploading them as well.

I will say this: This project is not for the faint of heart, and it is impossible without either 2 sets of hands, or some sort of incredibly clever way of holding pieces while you wire cut.

FT Viggen Page: https://www.flitetest.com/articles/ja-37-viggen-scratch-build

Viggen Build Blog: https://www.flitetest.com/articles/ja37-viggen-edf-build-log

I want to make a hot wire Viggen. I do not have a laser cutter, but I believe that by using a relatively heat resistant material such as ABS or PETG, I will be able to 3D print the templates, and hot wire cut the foam using 3D printed templates.

Depending on your material and your wire temp, you may need to reinforce the edges of the templates with superglue/epoxy, or expand them on the Z axis to make them thicker... But if your wire is adjustable temp, you should be able to cuz through foam just fine without damaging something like PETG.

I created these by tracing and then vectorizing the plans. I have not tested these templates yet, and have not begun wire cutting, but I wanted to get the files uploaded here as I do not see others like them anywhere else on the internet.

I will upload pictures of my progress as I go, and will be updating this project as needed.

These should be scaled correctly now, to verify, perhaps print the H (exhaust) first, the inner diameter should be 60mm. The F ones with the cutout are where the EDF go, and should be 70mm.

"The McDonnell Douglas MD-11 is an American three-engine medium- to long-range wide-body jet airliner, manufactured by McDonnell Douglas and, later, by Boeing Commercial Airplanes. Based on the DC-10, it features a stretched fuselage, increased wingspan with winglets, refined airfoils on the wing and smaller tailplane, new engines and increased use of composite materials. Two of its engines are mounted on underwing pylons and a third engine at the base of the vertical stabilizer. It also features a glass cockpit that decreases the flight deck crew to two from the three required on the DC-10 by eliminating the need for a flight engineer."
Wikipedia

I personally love airplanes, especially this one. While it doesn't fly passengers anymore, you can still see it carrying cargo around the world, taking advantage of the long ranges that it was built for. This model is made of many individual parts, intended to be printed alone and then assembled later. Note there is a fully assembled file, but I would not recommend printing it, as it would have to be a lot smaller and use a lot of support material. I'm not going to stop you, but I'm just sayin'.

For anyone interested in modifying this, please, go right ahead. I have included the STEP file for the project, and have linked the Fusion 360 cloud file here: http://a360.co/2kTjMAZ

Printer Brand:

PrintrBot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.25

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Many parts require support, including the Vertical Stabilizer Assembly, Engines 1 & 3, the Inner & Outer Wings, and the Wing Supporting Structures. Orientations should be correct from the STL's, but in the event they are not, use the following:
Engines 1 and 3 with the intake facing up (Yes, this results in the side with the tiny contact area touching the bed. I know, trust me)
Vertical Stabilizer: Vertically, as if it where on the plane.
Outer Wings: Inner side down, so the support tower holds up the winglet
Inner wings: Inner side down. This doesn't need much, but the mating surface is NOT flat.
Wing Supporting Structures: Same as on the airplane. Will require support all along bottom.
All other pieces: Any other pieces should NOT require support, as they all have a flat bottom. To make assembly easier, I would recommend printing the models vertically, so the parts will sit closer to each other once put together. Vertical= 1/2 Circle part on bed.
Just another quick note. The windows for the cockpit are quite small, and I would recommend printing them at as high a resolution as possible, just so the layer lines aren't too obvious, as they are right on the front of the plane here.

Assembly

All smaller pieces that slot into the main frame are undersized by .3mm, for a friction fit on most 3d printers. If this is too loose, I would recommend gluing it in, which is a good idea for the whole frame in general. This goes for parts like the engines, the wings, and the vertical and horizontal stabilizers, where they sit into another part. The cockpit windows have a slightly smaller clearance, but should still fit, as they are only held on 2 or 3 sides.
Before you slot any of the smaller parts together, I would assemble the main pieces, such as the fuselage and wings. Once that is all together, you can attach the other pieces.
This was designed using Fusion 360, working off original drawings of the MD-11. One was set up for each plane, allowing me to get reference measurements for all axes.

description.text:
This is a simple 2 part wall sconce that as it is implemented is used to distribute light from a ring of LEDs placed on the tray of the sconce. I wouldn't advise using a candle or even a votive on that tray as the heat would very likely damage the sphere, but one possibility is to use the sphere as a form to shape aluminum foil or the aluminum from a light duty cooking tray, and use that as a reflector, in which case a votive candle might work just fine. Well except for the soot.

I printed at .2 mm layer, 1.2 mm top and bottom as well as edges. I also rotated the 'stand' portion to print in the orientation that it would hang on the wall. As I was looking for this to be a very light item, I printed with 5% infill

You may wish to print at different sizes, or with different materials. You could put an led lamp within the quarter sphere, and print that with a natural or translucent material, try with various densities of infill to find out what works for you.

I've designed and added a led half ring to go on the tray. This will work OK with a cr2032 battery and 9 5mm leds. It is not perfect, but will work. Feel free to modify any or all of the elements to fit your own needs.

Designed in tinkercad

Step one, quarter sphere. Start with the half sphere and cut half of it off with a cut box.
Duplicate and grow the second sphere 2 mm in long dimension, 1 mm each in short dimension and height
Turn the smaller sphere into a cut and align with the two flat surfaces and centered in length, then merge.
Add a box reduce to 1mmx1mm in height and width, then span the sphere from one corner to the other with it. Merge these two objects
Grow the quarter sphere from 22x11x11, to the size that works for your printer. I went with 150x75x75mm
Add a half cylinder to cut out the 'hole' that will be the bottom of the sconce sphere.

Step 2, stand.
Make a copy of the quarter sphere part. This will be a cut for the top of the stand
Add a cylinder, lay it down and stretch it to the length you need. I went with 105mm, but you may choose a different size. I then aligned the sphere so that it was centered at what will be the 'top' of the stand, and a bit forward so that it will not be resting on the wall. Turn the quarter sphere into a cut and merge the two parts. I then cut 5mm off the 'back'
Using cut cylinders and cut boxes I built a keyway for hanging the sconce on a nail. I added a second so that if you are concerned you can use a second nail to give the sconce more stability. Optionally with the flat surface you can use 3M Command adhesive pull strips to mount the sconce to a wall.
Add a tray by starting with a cylinder, reduce the thickness to 5 mm, then expand the circle to something that works in your design. I went with 80x80mm. I then cut 20mm off of one 'edge' which will be the back of the stand. Turn this so that the rounds of the base and the stand are aligned the same, and center them then merge the two parts.

Download the stl files, slice and print.

title: Aquarium Bonsai Experiments
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been looking at a way to print mini-Bonsai trees for aquarium aquascaping purposes. My plan was to print a 3D structure, and then glue moss onto it, so that once grown, it would look like a tree.

My first attempt was a solid shape. And that looked OK, but then I realized I could create a Voronoi tiling that would give it a cholla-like effect but shaped like a bonsai tree. That would also allow fish and the greens to live in the tree. I'll update once the moss has had a chance to grow.

The original design is in OpenScad, but soon after I pulled it into meshmixer and was able to generate the skeletal tiling by reducing the mesh and then taking the dual.

title: DAVLL Solenoid Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a design for a DAVLL solenoid cylinder. The magnet wire is coiled around the cylinder between two ridges on each half.

The two halves fit a standard 26mm x 80mm atomic vapor cylinder when joined together. The notch at the connecting end of each cylinder fits the nub in the middle of the vapor cell. Each half is designed to mount using a standard quarter inch optics screw (~7mm thread dia. and 10mm head dia.). The screw hole is accessible even with the vapor cell in place. I designed this so it could be printed without the need for support material. Important design note: The inside diameter of the female sleeve connector is 0.2mm larger than the exterior of the male connector. This is because I have noticed that the particular printer I'm using tends to print holes (but not exterior dimensions) slightly smaller than the dimensions specified in the CAD files. Whatever printer you use might be different, so adjust accordingly for a good fit. See and edit on Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/6XzdNRMyl5A

This is a small part that allows you to stack these small shelves on top of each other. It's a small $20 wire rack shelf unit with 3 shelves. The model is #0328961. Will also fit a small unit from Amazon.

To use, pop the black plastic cap out of one assembled shelf and place one printed part in each corner post. Next shelf must be assembled with the legs upside down (one end has threads for adjustable feet but we need the top to connect to the top of the other shelf, don't worry, nothing lost by assembling upside down.

Then simply place the second shelf on top of the printed pars. Your done!

description.text:
I wanted a light system that did not require me to tape, glue, or drill. Plus I wanted something that would not give out and fall down over time. So I had a idea of using clips to connect to the glass. I did not see anything similar on thingiverse. So I decided to make my first make.

The center middle piece (led center bar v4.stl) I did use double side 3m tape to attach. If it does give out the clips on both sides will prevent it from falling.

The clips fits perfectly on a .225in (5mm) thick plexiglass. Can upload different sizes if anyone used thinner glass for their enclosure. It should work if you have thinner glass since the top of the enclosure will hold it in place.

The railing is to prevent any gaps the clips might create and makes a nice look. Plus hides any blemish cutting the glass might of caused.

The complete set that I used are - 12 LED Clips, 12 railings, and 2 center led bar holder.

I used LED 3528 purchased from amazon.

comments.author: daanvanderkolk

comments.text: Just printed the cage and spiral mixers in a scaled down version to fit on a dremel. Stood the cage on end, spiral on its side, rafted each with support everywhere on the spiral. Both turned out well. My basic idea was to have a mixer that would fit in an airbrush bottle. I mounted the cage to a dremel disc sander fitting. The spiral fit well over a heated 1/8" steel rod for hand mixing and is perfect by all accounts.

title: Eureka 7 Compac Drive
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Compac Drive is a device used mainly to allow a human to interface with machinery, such as vehicles and computers. While there is little information as to the exact nature of the Compac Drive, it appears that it acts as an interface with whatever it is hooked up to, from simple machines, such as motorcycles, to more advanced heavy machinery, such as LFOs.

There are three STL files:

  1. Compac Drive Blank, which has no words scrolled down the side.
  2. Compac Drive Eureka, which has the name Eureka scrolled down the side.
  3. Compac Drive, which has the name Eureka scrolled down the side and the Amita Drive attached.

Let me know what you guys think! Please let me know what works and what doesn't, as well as any suggestions of what else you may like to see on thingiverse. I started making Eureka 7 stuff because I couldn't find them anywhere else. Happy printing!
